attributes.description: The tomato is the fruit of the tomato plant, a member of the Nightshade family (Solanaceae). The fruit grows on a sprawling vine that is often trellised or caged to keep it upright. There are many kinds of tomatoes, including conventional, hybrid, heirloom, plum, grape, and cherry. Determinate or bush varieties do not need pruning and can be grown without trellises or cages. Indeterminate or climbing varieties benefit from pruning and should be trellised, caged, or staked.
attributes.sowing_method: Direct seed indoors, transplant seedlings outside after hardening off

Mix of heirlooms and san marzanos in containers.
One plant from the grocery store, already a solid 1.5' tall, and two sprouts from seed that I don't expect to really go anywhere.
Abraham Lincoln cultivar -- one of the two that survived starting from seed. Seed from Burpee's, given out for free last year as part of the USDA sesquicentennial celebration.

These are tomatoes that came up volunteers from last year's Cherry Tomato Plant That Ate The Greater Metropolitan Area.  They are many. They are growing. I poke them with sticks occasionally and otherwise try to stay out of their business.

Whoa, 14 have germinated within a week. I planted that many because I expected nearly all of them to fail.

Fed, soaped, going well.

9 pots up nd down the front stairs. Had started in mainly shade on porch and grew too tall for the cages. Are producing well now with miracle gro and sun
Principe tomatoes.  Small golf ball sized fruits, again from seed savers.  Common in Italy where it is a primary sauce tomato.  I use the sauce fresh and frozen.  Very (read too) productive.
2 each- white, black and cherry in 4x3. Suuuuuper tall, had to trim. Too close together
Beefsteak. 6 in 4x3. Too crowded to maintain easily, but they seem to be growing well.
Sungold (2), Illini Star (2), Gypsy (1), Pink Berkeley Tie Dye (1), Malakhitovaya Shkatulka (1), orange and green zebra (1)
Roots Down Organic
Roma

Enchantment, Sunsugar, Brandyboy and Opalka

Opalka perished overnight, apparently it was in a dry spot somehow. Others are doing well.

EDIT: Sunsugar - OK yield, the soil was too poor for it I think. Pretty good yield from brandy boy. Enchantment produced SO MANY TOMATOES.

Golden Nugget Cherry, Sweet Baby Girl Cherry, Black Krim Heirloom, Pineapple Heirloom, Creole Heirloom... all purchased as seedlings online from Garden Harvest Supply (www.gardenharvestsupply.com) and sent through the mail. So far, plants are huge and lush with plenty of flowers and fruit, but only the Baby Girl Cherry has been producing, and very sparsely. Plants are probably overcrowded (there is also basil and peppers planted in the same 4'x4' plot). Wish I'd used tomato cages to get their growth more upward, instead of dense and thick low to the ground like it is now. Live and learn!
Some tommy toes, and some mixed heirloom from diggers. Mystery box tomatoes!

This year's tomatoes:
San Marzano
Brandy Boy
Persimmon
[4th of July|Arkansas Traveler] (I was looking at both and I forget which I picked)
Self sown and transplanted
"green zebra" variety
Separate varities - Tom Thumb, Rouge De Marmande, Cherokee Purple, Scoresby Dwarf (Ky1)

They recovered amazingly, but I don't expect much of a harvest.

Planting date approx, bought from local grower on a Saturday morning at Bar Francis/The Northern.

Four varieties:
Tess's Land Race Currant
Can't remember other three at the moment.

Sept 3 - been harvesting abt 3/day of the Currant tomatoes. This morning noticed the Black Cherry & Black Zim (?) starting to turn red!

Sept 16 - Currants are steady producers and very tasty. Have gotten a couple Black Cherry, harvested all 5 Black Zims, some not edible (over-ripe? too much rain?). Still none of the last variety.

Sept 21 - Pulled the Black Zims, harvested the 1st of the other slicing tomato.

Started coming up 15/9/2014

Of all the types of tomato I've ever tried to grow here, the Pink Egg is the only one that I'd say has "worked". Others have survived for a certain period and given a few resentful, bland tomatoes but the pink eggs produce like mad and they taste quite good, and don't have any problem with pests, disease, or cracking like the others do. The fruit is beautiful colours and the size is between a cherry and a roma. They produce well in the dry season and will keep growing through the wet (but will not fruit, the humidity messes with pollination). If you nurse them through a wet season they'll start fruiting again as soon as the weather dries up a bit.

A variety of varieties, planted out from pots. Not sure how they'll do, to be honest, but I'm expecting to get at least a few tomatoes off them.  Varieties include jaune flamme, lemon drop, wild sweetie, green zebra, and not sure what else to be honest!

Abraham Lincoln heirloom variety -- I got the seed packet free at a gardening outreach thing last year. There were only 7 seeds in it, but it will be interesting to see what happens. Transplanted on 15 May 2013 to containers. When they're taller, I'll put them in the ground. 02-Jun-2013: only 2 have survived, but are almost the size to transplant safely into the ground. 15 Jun 13 -- transplanted one into ground. 23 June 2013 -- transplanted last Abraham Lincoln into community garden

Initially planted indoors. 2 planted out on the 17th May 2015. 6 more acquired from the mother PWithnall and planted directly outside. (Originally sown from seed by the granda PWithnall in March 2015.) As of 18th May 2015 five are still inside waiting for the strength to move outside.

2015-06-04: Another 3 planted outside. 2 remain indoors.

started at home under lights, planted in earthboxes.

built two 4'x8' beds at my friends place.  Removed sod, turned soil, added branches (similar to hugelculture, but without building it into a berm) and leaves, then topsoil.  Tomato plants were planted directly into topsoil, and next to tripods to "climb" instead of tomato cages.
Jaunne Flamme (I think), bought at MD Sheep and Wool
Variety "Bloody Butcher".
planted north to south along edge of 6 ft high trellis at about 60 cm spacings to match my dripper layout/1 ft gardening
Self-seeded tomatoes that have sprouted from compost around dwarf beans. Moved about 4 away from beans, left two where they are. May not get any fruit off them before autumn.
Self-seeded tomatoes that have sprouted from compost around dwarf beans. May not get any fruit off them before autumn. Transplanted: 2 (3?) to sunny spaces by hedge; 2 in shadow of hedge.

Tag reads: "Oregon Spring, Earliest tomatos (57 days), cold hardy, indeterminate, www.colecanyonfarm.com, certified organic by CCOF".

Planted in a single Earthbox on a south-facing balcony.

Update early June: Tomato-eating time! There are 25+ red or orange tomatoes on the plants.

2013-08-24: These plants really stopped being productive about a month ago. We took down one of them and expect to take down the other one shortly as well.

2013-09-08: Retired.
Many different varieties, amish paste are a new heirloom i'm trying this year

The seeds were started inside in a sunny south window, then trained on a balcony facing south and put on a balcony facing nw early in the summer (probably end of May, start of June). 

Two plants have more sun than the others and are giving a lot more tomatoes. The one tomato plant in the most shade is not doing well now that the weather is turning a bit colder and the sun isn't around as much as in the summer. Will not give crop, so do not put tomatoes there, unless higher up (more sun, warmer).

The plants directly on the floor and in the smallest containers (planted alone) are doing worst, while those in bigger containers and together (2 and 2) have gotten big and at the time being (17.9.2014) turning tomatoes red daily.
Actually it self-seeded from compost, so it's probably a supermarket hybrid.

(date approx)

2014-08-07: Flowering and transplanted to a larger pot on north-facing balcony with a cage. I think this may be a red cherry tomato variety.

2014-10-04: Caged a second flowering volunteer plant on the south-facing balcony. I think this may be the olive variety. Gave away a bunch of other seedlings

2014-10-26: Red cherry variety has a few ripe tomatoes. Repotted 2 September seedlings to Earthbox on south-facing balcony.

2014-12-14: Retired not-very-productive plant.

2015-01-09: Retired remaining not-very-productive plants.

"Indigo rose" plum sized tomatoes.

2014-07-22: Potted in earthbox on south-facing balcony.

2014-10-06 (approx): Ate first tomatoes.

2014-11-29: Still yielding many tomatoes.

2014-12-27: Retired plant before travel, as the plant had many remaining tomatoes but they weren't ripening.
variety: Patio

"Sweet Olive. Space 18-24'' apart in rows 36-48'' apart. Full sun. Harvest at 57-63 days. This new grape tomato is sweet, bite-size, bright red and bursting with flavor. Their outstanding texture and perfect blend of sweet-tart taste make them a natural snack and a perfect addition to salads. The medium tall plants are easy-to-grow, productive and manageable without pruning. Determinate plant habit."

2014-05-17: Ate first tomatoes!

2015-01-09: I can't believe how long this plant has kept at it, and with little maintenance. I retired one of the plants which had a bunch of new flowers on it (but no tomatoes), and left the other.

2015-03-01: Finally retired. The last few tomatoes weren't that good, and we probably could have just retired this in December.

"Visitacion Valley. Wicked good! Bright red, 3 oz oval fruit. The best flavor of any salad-type, super-early tomato. Rich, sweet tomato flavor. Compact plants are semi-determinate. 65 days. Space 18-24'' (46-61 cm) apart in rows 18-24'' (46-61 cm) apart. Full sun. Prefers consistent soil moisture."

Purchased seedling that already had a couple tiny tomatoes on it.
Planted in earthbox on south-facing balcony.

2014-05-10: Ate first tomatoes!

2014-05-24: So many tomatoes!

2014-07-22: Retired early, yielding another ~4 dozen tomatoes.
Six well established seedlings from Gerlinde's garden. Each in their own pot. When the fence is fixed I'll put their bamboo tripods in.

Date approx.

Volunteer cherry tomato plants.
Planted on the north-facing balcony.

Dozens of seeds sprouted. We gave most of the seedlings away.

We also had a few volunteers in early June, which have been productive despite being kept in small pots.

2013-12-28: Retired. Few additional tomatoes ripened off the vine.

"Japanese Black Trifele Tomato"
Mid-sized pear-shaped tomato. Very large leaves; I suspect this is not really a container variety.

2013-09-12: First ripe tomatoes picked.

2013-10-01 - 2013-10-07: Juiced many many tomatoes.

2013-10-12: Retired one of the two plants.

Tag reads: "Heirloom tomato Pineapple. Space 18-24'' apart in rows 36-48'' apart. Full sun. 85-90 days. An heirloom garden favorite that grows fruits up to 2 pounds! These bicolor yellow and pink fruits have a beautiful red starburst in the center. The flavor is tropically sweet, fruity and complex. This one is a show stopper! A fantastic heirloom. 85 Days Indeterminate Bragger Size. Vintage Veggies."

Planted in a single Earthbox on a south-facing balcony.

Update early June: Tomato-eating time! There are 25+ red or orange tomatoes on the plants.

Mid June: Om nom nom! 

Sadly, I was traveling through the second half of endless tomatoes. The plant was taken down on/around July 4.
